title: How to Keep a Cat Off a Stove

steps.title: Discourage your cat with sticky placemats along the countertops.
steps.content: Discourage your cat with sticky placemats along the countertops. [1] X Expert Source Jessica Char Cat & Dog Behavior Consultant Expert Interview. 28 September 2021. Pick up a few plastic placemats from the store and cover a single side with strips of double-sided tape. Arrange these sticky placemats along the edge of the kitchen counter near your stove, or wherever your cat typically leaps to. Cats really hate the sticky feeling of tape beneath their paws, which makes this option effective. [2] X Trustworthy Source Animal Humane Society Leading animal welfare nonprofit organization providing medical care, training education, and resources for animal owners Go to source Once your cat breaks their bad counter- and stove-surfing habit, you can remove the placemats from your kitchen.

steps.title: Cover parts of your countertop with aluminum foil or bubble wrap.
steps.content: Cover parts of your countertop with aluminum foil or bubble wrap. [3] X Expert Source Jessica Char Cat & Dog Behavior Consultant Expert Interview. 28 September 2021. Keep an eye out for your cat’s reaction as they jump on these surfaces. For some reason, cats hate the feeling of foil or bubble wrap, and may learn not to jump near the stove this way. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Deter your cat with compressed air.
steps.content: Deter your cat with compressed air. Spray your cat a spritz of compressed air whenever they jump on the stove-top or nearby countertops. Only squirt the air around their back and chest—don’t spray it near their eyes or nose, which are pretty sensitive. Don’t let your cat see you squirt them—you want them to think that the gust of air came out of nowhere, not from you. You can also use a spray bottle to spritz your cat with water instead of using compressed air. You can also use “Ssscat,” a special motion-sensing item that sprays your cat with compressed air whenever it notices your cat slinking near the stove. [5] X Research source [6] X Expert Source Rita Reimers Cat Behaviorist Expert Interview. 22 June 2021.

steps.title: Wipe down your countertops and stove with a citrus cleaner.
steps.content: Wipe down your countertops and stove with a citrus cleaner. Pick up a pet-friendly citrus cleaning spray that you can spritz near your countertops and stove area. Cats aren’t a fan of this scent, and the smell may keep them away from your stove. Plus, it’ll help you keep your kitchen clean! Double-check the label to make sure the cleaning spray is safe for pets. You might have more luck finding a safe spray at a pet store. Cats also aren’t a big fan of citronella, aloe, wintergreen, or eucalyptus scents. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Tell your cat "no" and physically take them off the stove.
steps.content: Tell your cat "no" and physically take them off the stove. Sometimes, basic discipline can get the job done! When you notice your cat on or near the stove, pick them up and place them on the ground. As you do this, firmly say “no,” so your cat knows not to jump near the stove again. [8] X Expert Source Rita Reimers Cat Behaviorist Expert Interview. 22 June 2021. Stay calm whenever you discipline your cat. While shouting may seem more effective, this could scare your cat instead of really teaching them anything. [9] X Expert Source Rita Reimers Cat Behaviorist Expert Interview. 22 June 2021. Don't reward your cat after taking him off the countertop. [10] X Expert Source Rita Reimers Cat Behaviorist Expert Interview. 22 June 2021.

steps.title: Block common landing areas on the countertop.
steps.content: Block common landing areas on the countertop. Keep an eye on your cat throughout the week, studying where they tend to leap on the counter and stove. Move items around on your counter so these landing spaces are blocked off. [11] X Research source For instance, if you keep your spices on the countertop, move these around near your stove, so your cat can’t jump up onto that area.

steps.title: Startle your cat with precarious cookie sheets.
steps.content: Startle your cat with precarious cookie sheets. Arrange cookie sheets along the edge of the countertop, with 1 side partially dangling off. As your cat jumps onto the counter, they’ll actually land on the cookie sheet, which will fall and make a clanging noise. This may give your cat a bad association with counter-surfing, and keep your cat off the stove in the future. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Don’t punish your cat for jumping on the stove.
steps.content: Don’t punish your cat for jumping on the stove. Counter- and stove-surfing are definitely annoying, but obvious punishments, like shouting at your pet, won’t accomplish anything except make your furry friend extra nervous and possibly afraid of you. [13] X Trustworthy Source Animal Humane Society Leading animal welfare nonprofit organization providing medical care, training education, and resources for animal owners Go to source Additionally, never push your cat off the stove or counter, or else your furry friend might get hurt by accident. Instead, look into subtle ways to convince your cat to hang out in another part of your home. Some cats will lash out when punished, and try to bite you or refuse to use their litter boxes. [14] X Trustworthy Source Animal Humane Society Leading animal welfare nonprofit organization providing medical care, training education, and resources for animal owners Go to source

steps.title: Put out cat trees and pieces of furniture your cat can jump on.
steps.content: Put out cat trees and pieces of furniture your cat can jump on. Cats love to climb to high places, which is why they enjoy leaping on countertops and stoves in the first place. Keep your pets entertained by giving them plenty of safe places to climb, like cat trees. [15] X Expert Source Jessica Char Cat & Dog Behavior Consultant Expert Interview. 28 September 2021. You can also set up furniture in a separate room that’s safe for your cat to climb and explore, like a bookshelf. [16] X Research source If your cat is distracted with fun, safe climbing areas, they might not spend as much time near your stove. Place your cat tree near a window so your cat can see outside. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Spend time with your cat each day so they don’t feel ignored.
steps.content: Spend time with your cat each day so they don’t feel ignored. Cats sometimes counter-surf because they’re looking for attention. Carve some time out of your day to give your furry friend a little extra TLC—this may help satisfy your cat’s need for attention, and keep them from jumping onto the stove when you’re in the kitchen. [18] X Trustworthy Source Animal Humane Society Leading animal welfare nonprofit organization providing medical care, training education, and resources for animal owners Go to source

steps.title: Reward your cat with extra goodies in an approved area.
steps.content: Reward your cat with extra goodies in an approved area. [19] X Expert Source Jessica Char Cat & Dog Behavior Consultant Expert Interview. 28 September 2021. Set up a treat-dispensing toy in a separate area near a cat condo, cat tree, or another place where your pet can play safely. This toy encourages your pets to stay in one area, and away from your stove and countertop. [20] X Trustworthy Source Animal Humane Society Leading animal welfare nonprofit organization providing medical care, training education, and resources for animal owners Go to source

steps.title: Encourage your cat to stay off the counter or stove with a clicker.
steps.content: Encourage your cat to stay off the counter or stove with a clicker. [21] X Expert Source Jessica Char Cat & Dog Behavior Consultant Expert Interview. 28 September 2021. Pay attention to whenever your cat jumps off the stovetop or nearby counter. Place your cat’s favorite treat on the ground, and click a special cat clicker right as your furry friend eats the treat. Repeat this process whenever your cat hops on the stove—eventually, they’ll associate the sound of the clicker with tasty treats! You can find pet clickers online, or at pet supply stores.
